content: It would be interesting if the first mountain could start from a different index, rather than always starting at zero.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I love the task and it is perfect for clash of code.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it checks every checkbox and intersting exercise

It took me 5 minutes to understand the problem, but only through the comments below that spoke about a "photo". Or maybe you can write about a "vertical cut".
The "0" are very misleading too. A "." or space would be better.
"#" is not a mountain, it is simply rocks that compose the mountain above it.

After understanding, in fact you are only looking for the 0-index of the column with the most "#". If you have this as "Goal", it makes for a very good CoC.

Here it is more a simple solo Puzzle once you have understood the problem.

I like this one. +1 from me. I golfed it with 55 characters.

Some suggestions that should make your statement clearer:

* Change the zeros in the inputs to spaces. That way it's much easier to see the mountain shape. That should make a huge difference, especially for reverse mode.
* In the first example, the mountain isn't connected to the ground everywhere. That contrasts with all the test cases (so it might be confusing, especially in reverse mode). Consider connecting every peak in the first example to the ground.
* Change the wording from tallest mountain to tallest peak everywhere.
* Related to the above, if a position in the mountain range is not a peak, call it a column instead of a mountain.
* Don't use "range of hills" in the first sentence. Use "mountain range" instead, like everywhere else.
* Move the sentence "There will be n lines, each consisting ..." from the goal statement to the input statement, and rewrite it to fit in.
* Move the first sentence of the example ("The time it takes to reach the ith mountain...") to the goal statement, between the other two sentences.
* Remove the sentence "You can't move across air". I think it's unnecessary if you already say only horizontal distance counts.

I have justifications for all these points. I left most of them out. Ask if you want to know.
Good luck getting approvals!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looking at the desc again, I realize it might be confusing, but this was one of the least problem free COC that I have done, I automatically jumped to the conclusion that you start in the left most column and have inf jump height, this is not exactly what it seems to say, but the solution was intuitive enough for me.

Goal section
* How do I know which mountain is mountain 1?

* How do you define the height of a mountain?

* How do I move from one spot to another? Only horizontally and vertically? How about diagonally?

* Should I assume I cannot move across air?

Input section
* Please change "mountains" to "a line in the map of air and mountains".

Constraints section
* Please change "are" to "is".

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement.

Thanks.

55 char noice
Ruby is really OP.
I'm pretty sure it was python, since I don't know ruby. I remade it from scratch and got it down to 53 this time.

I genuinely don't understand your statement.

By the way, please don't leave irrelevant comments on contributions. I've deleted some of them.
IDK how to define the height of a mountain?
You ask the player to find the tallest mountain. Then how does the player know which one is the tallest if they don't know how to find out the heights?

"first mountain in the first mountain"? That's certainly some description...

I finally see what you mean by mountains. It's so difficult to recognise the shapes of mountains among those 0 and # characters!

I also misinterpreted the input as a MAP instead of a PHOTO. That's why I was thinking, "oh, how do I move from one cell to another cell"? Clear descriptions are important, dude!

Input section
* Please change "map" to "photo".

Goal section
* Suggest to change "Mountain 1 is always the first mountain in the first mountain (first column)" to:

The first column always contains a mountain and is denoted as Mountain 1. A mountain always starts on the ground (the bottom row) and continues up to its peak.

* It also feels weird to describe each column as a single mountain. I would consider columns of mountain which are connected together as a single mountain range. It's more appropriate to describe the task as finding the time to reach the peak of any mountain range.

* Also, the time you request to output takes into account only the horizontal distance and ignores any vertical (climbing) distance. That should be mentioned.

Thanks.

Mountain 1 is always the first mountain in the first mountain (first column)
lmao bru
Then you should say that mountain index 0 is actually 1.
